review.title: Equilibrium Graphs
review.abstract: In this paper we present an extension of Peirce's existential graphs to provide a diagrammatic representation of expressions in Quantified Equilibrium Logic (QEL). Using this formalisation, logical connectives are replaced by encircled regions (circles and squares) and quantified variables are represented as "identity" lines. Although the expressive power is equivalent to that of QEL, the new representation can be useful for illustrative or educational purposes.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: By introducing a minimal deviation from Peirce's existential graph (the introduction of rectangles), we have presented a diagrammatic representation of the Quantified Equilibrium Logic and the ASP programs. In fact, the current formulation allows the representation of any intermediate logic since it has only just made it possible to define implications, disjunctions, and universal quantification as primitive constructions, rather than derived operators in terms of conjunction, negation, and existential quantifications.This note is a preliminary proposal, but evidently much remains to be done. First, it is still unclear how to provide a fully visual semantic characterization, especially for beta diagrams. Another desirable feature would be a set of consequences and equivalence diagrams that circumscribe rules covering QHT in a solid and complete way.From the ASP perspective, it is interesting to note that QAPEL does not have a direct ASP formula to begin with: ASP is not a form equivalent to ASP.

However, save few exceptions (like their influence in Sowa’s conceptual graphs [3]), the truth is that EGs did not gain the same popularity as the symbolic notation for classical logic, even though they provide an elegant and simple representation that seems very suitable for educational purposes.

In this paper we study an extension of existential graphs to be used as an alternative diagrammatic notation for Answer Set Programming [6–8] (ASP) and, in particular, for its logical formalisation in terms of Equilibrium Logic [9].

Proposed by David Pearce, Equilibrium Logic has allowed the application of the stable model semantics [10], originally defined for the syntax of logic programs, to the case of arbitrary propositional formulas.

Moreover, the extension to the first-order case, known as Quantified Equilibrium Logic [11], provides nowadays a general logical notion of stable models for arbitrary theories expressed in the syntax of First-Order Logic.
Equilibrium Logic is defined by imposing a model selection criterion on top of a monotonic intermediate logic known as the logic of Here-and-There [12] (HT).

Something similar happens in Quantified HT [11] where, again, the existential quantifier is definable in terms of the universal one, but it is much more convenient to treat both of them as primitive connectives.
A first difficulty we face is that implication is a primitive operator in HT, and cannot be represented in terms of conjunction and disjunction (see Theorem 4 in [13]).
Finally, regarding implementation, a promising line to explore would be the integration of this graphical notation into a visual tool for ASP like the one in [14].
